pr_title: Remove previously deprecated methods and types

timeline.message: Remove previously deprecated methods and types

timeline.bodyText: actually, I don't think this one should be removed :( It looks like it was deprecated by mistake, because ultimately the one we'd want removed is the one with a Consumer<Subscription> (see the TODO on subscribe variant with such a Consumer below)
timeline.author: simonbasle
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -1052,25 +1025,6 @@ public final Disposable subscribe(
 		return this.subscribe(onNext, onError, onComplete, onSubscribe, null);
 	}
 
-	/**
-	 * Subscribes to this {@link ParallelFlux} by providing an onNext, onError and
-	 * onComplete callback as well as an initial {@link Context}, then trigger the execution chain for all
-	 * 'rails'.
-	 *
-	 * @param onNext consumer of onNext signals
-	 * @param onError consumer of error signal
-	 * @param onComplete callback on completion signal
-	 * @param initialContext {@link Context} for the rails
-	 */
-	@Deprecated

replies.bodyText: please revert the removal of that method, and delete the @Deprecated instead 🙇
replies.author: simonbasle

timeline.bodyText: The implementation FluxRetryPredicate can most likely also be deleted. Please double check remaining relevant tests are either kept in this test class or moved to FluxRetryWhenTest as a @Nested test maybe?
timeline.author: simonbasle
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -41,19 +42,13 @@ public void sourceNull() {
 		new FluxRetryPredicate<>(null, e -> true);

timeline.bodyText: there was no "to be removed" even though this one has been deprecated since 3.3.1... I wonder if there could be anybody out there testing that no onSubscribe happens for a given duration (which would be a legitimate-ish verification). Can restore it for now and open an issue for that specific case to remove the method and add a suitable alternative in a follow-up PR ?
timeline.author: simonbasle

replies.bodyText: But no onSubscribe after subscribe() would be a spec violation, isn't it?
replies.author: bsideup

replies.bodyText: yes, but a delayed onSubscribe wouldn't.
replies.author: simonbasle

replies.bodyText: right... used to be a gray area. let's remove it then, even though the @Deprecated was intended as a deterrent to using that method without at least thinking about calling expectSubscription().
replies.author: simonbasle

timeline.message: un-deprecate some methods, remove unused classes

timeline.bodyText: the tests of removed retry operators should either be moved to xxxRetryWhenTest or there should be a comment in that test class pointing to xxxRetryPredicateTest. also there are SuppressWarnings("deprecation") in these tests that are not necessary anymore
timeline.author: simonbasle
